Award.AwardTitle: Ligand Scaffold Optimization for Catalytic Asymmetric Hydroboration
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will continue work on the development of chiral self-assembled ligands and catalysts for the catalytic asymmetric hydroboration of alkenes. Chirality-directed self-assembly enables the rapid in situ preparation of dozens, even hundreds, of unique ligand scaffolds and thus permits the subtle structural manipulation of catalyst topography in ways not available with classical ligand designs. While stoichiometric asymmetric hydroboration is widely used, the catalyzed reaction is underdeveloped relative to its potential utility in asymmetric synthesis. Combinatorial type screening of chiral self-assembled ligands will be carried out to identify new useful supramolecular catalysts. Studies to further elucidate the reasons for the success of these catalysts will be undertaken to provide new fundamental insight into asymmetric catalysis.

With this award, the Organic and Macromolecular Chemistry Program is supporting the research of Professor Takacs of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. Professor Takacs? research efforts revolve around the development of supramolecular catalysts using self-assembly to generate macromolecular scaffolds that define the shape and characteristics required for efficient catalysis, an approach that mimics biological catalysts. This application focuses on the formation of synthetically useful and versatile C-B bonds via metal-catalyzed hydroboration, a reaction that holds significant untapped potential for asymmetric synthesis. Such chemistry holds the promise to replace a stoichiometric reaction protocol with a catalytic one and thus contribute to environmentally benign methods for chemical synthesis. Successful development of the methodology will have an impact on synthesis in the pharmaceutical and agricultural industries.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This basic research project in synthetic organic chemistry developed hydroboration chemistry for asymmetric synthesis which has potential practical applications in the pharmaceutical industry for drug synthesis. In addition, the project led to several conceptual advances for the field of chemistry and perhaps beyond. It was shown that substrates that can bind the hydroboration catalyst with two functional groups greatly enhance the rate and selectivity of the chemical reaction. While the catalyzed hydroboration reaction has been known for more than 20 years, these two-point binding substrates use very simple chiral catalysts and greatly expands the scope of usable substrates, that is, greatly expands the types of structures that can be synthesized (see CAHB graphic).

The second concept is related to the design supramolecular catalysts.  Supramolecular catalysts are different from the small molecule catalysts that chemists traditionally develop. The concept is to have small pieces (subunits or modules) spontaneously self-assemble into functional catalysts. The goal is to design chemocatalysts that exhibit the characteristics of biocatalysts (i.e., enzymes). This is perhaps one of the grand challenges for synthetic chemistry, and as such, it attracts much research. The question is how to do it?

Most practitioners start with the idea building a rigid binding pocket that will encapsulate an organic substrate and then attempt to engineer in “active sites” around this pocket that can catalyze reaction of the bound substrate.  Enzymes on the other hand first evolved the active site, preserved it through evolutionary history, and then built a soft binding site around the active site to effect reactions selectively. The latter is the approach taken in this project. Use a simple metal catalyst that catalyzes a reaction efficiently, but non-selectively, and then use self-assembly to build a soft binding pocket around this active site. A combinatorial (informed, semi-random) approach is used to rapidly modify the active site in hundreds of subtly different ways. The key accomplishment on this part of the project was in taking the most successful supramolecular catalysts and deconvoluting the contributions of the various subunits that make up its unique structure. The resulting insights have impact for chemistry and perhaps beyond to biological chemistry (see Catalyst Scaffold Optimization Graphic).

 The other broader impacts of the project are in training. This project involved undergraduates and graduate students at the University of Nebraska and elsewhere. Three students earned their doctorates and are employed in research; four earned masters degrees and are either employed in research or pursuing doctoral degrees. Faculty from two predominantly undergraduate institutions also participated in this research giving exposure to students at their respective institutions as well. Other local and an international collaboration also played a significant role in this research.


Last Modified: 03/02/2014
Modified by: James M Takacs
